value.text: heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

text:
Primary Diagnosis: Acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), anterior wall

Key Symptoms/Signs: Acute crushing substernal chest pain, Pain 9/10, diaphoretic, S4 gallop ,bibasilar crackles.

Diagnostic Evidence: ST elevation 3mm in leads V2-V5, 100% occlusion of mid-LAD with thrombus,TIMI-3 flow.

Procedure Performed: Emergent cardiac catheterization, Drug-eluting stent

Complications: None

Discharge Status:  Stable,  chest pain free, ambulating without difficulty

Extra Note: no relief with nitroglycerin

data.text: ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), anterior wall PATIENT: 62-year-old male with hypertension, diabetes, and 40 pack-year smoking history presents with acute crushing substernal chest pain radiating to left arm, onset 90 minutes ago while mowing lawn. Associated with diaphoresis, nausea, and dyspnea. Pain 9/10 intensity, no relief with nitroglycerin. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Vitals: BP 165/95, HR 108, RR 22, O2 sat 94% on room air. Patient diaphoretic, anxious, in acute distress. S4 gallop present, bibasilar crackles noted. LABORATORY RESULTS: Troponin I 3.8 ng/mL (markedly elevated), CK-MB 128 ng/mL (elevated), glucose 245 mg/dL, LDL 178 mg/dL. ELECTROCARDIOGRAM: ST elevation 3mm in leads V2-V5 consistent with anterior STEMI. Q waves in V2-V3. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Emergent cardiac catheterization revealed 100% occlusion of mid-LAD with thrombus. Drug-eluting stent placed successfully, TIMI-3 flow restored. HOSPITAL COURSE: Aspirin 325mg and clopidogrel 600mg administered immediately. Heparin bolus and infusion started. Metoprolol 25mg PO given after hemodynamic stabilization. Morphine 4mg IV for pain control, chest pain resolved post-procedure. Post-procedure echocardiogram showed ejection fraction 40%. Started on sacubitril-valsartan for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: Acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction, anterior wall, status post drug-eluting stent to LAD. Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. CONSULTATIONS: Cardiology, cardiac rehabilitation CONDITION ON DISCHARGE: Stable, chest pain free, ambulating without difficulty DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS: Aspirin 81mg PO daily, ticagrelor 90mg PO twice daily, atorvastatin 80mg PO at bedtime, metoprolol succinate 50mg PO daily, sacubitril-valsartan 24/26mg PO twice daily, lisinopril 5mg PO daily DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: Continue dual antiplatelet therapy for minimum 12 months. Follow up with cardiology clinic in 1 week. Attend cardiac rehabilitation. Strict smoking cessation. Monitor blood glucose closely. Return immediately for chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations.

value.text: left ventricular hypertrophy by voltage criteria

text:
Primary Diagnosis: Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis

Key Symptoms/Signs: syncope, dyspnea,Harsh 3/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, diminished S2, delayed carotid upstroke

Diagnostic Evidence:heavily calcified, immobile valve leaflets, Aortic valve area 0.7 cm², mean gradient 52 mmHg, peak velocity 4.8 m/s, valve area 0.65 cm²

Procedure Performed: transfemoral transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR), temporary pacing

Complications: transient complete heart block

Discharge Status: Stable, improved dyspnea, ambulating without difficulty

data.text: ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis with syncope and dyspnea PATIENT: 78-year-old female with history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and remote rheumatic fever presents with progressive exertional dyspnea and two episodes of near-syncope over past month. Symptoms occur with minimal exertion. Denies chest pain. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Vitals: BP 135/65 (wide pulse pressure), HR 68, O2 sat 97% on room air. Harsh 3/6 crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at right upper sternal border radiating to carotids. Diminished S2, delayed carotid upstroke noted (pulsus parvus et tardus). ELECTROCARDIOGRAM: Sinus rhythm, left ventricular hypertrophy by voltage criteria ECHOCARDIOGRAM: Severe aortic stenosis with heavily calcified, immobile valve leaflets. Aortic valve area 0.7 cm² (severe <1.0 cm²), mean gradient 52 mmHg (severe >40 mmHg), peak velocity 4.8 m/s. Left ventricular hypertrophy present, LVEF 55% preserved. CARDIAC CATHETERIZATION: No significant coronary artery disease. Confirmed severe aortic stenosis with calculated valve area 0.65 cm². PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Successful transfemoral transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) with 26mm CoreValve prosthesis on hospital day 3. HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient and family elected TAVR over surgical aortic valve replacement given age and patient preference. Procedure uncomplicated with immediate gradient reduction. Post-procedure echocardiogram showed well-seated prosthetic valve, mean gradient 8 mmHg (excellent), no paravalvular leak. Developed transient complete heart block post-procedure requiring temporary pacing, resolved by day 2. Permanent pacemaker not required. Ambulating without difficulty by day 3. Dyspnea significantly improved. DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis, status post transcatheter aortic valve replacement CONSULTATIONS: Cardiology, interventional cardiology CONDITION ON DISCHARGE: Stable, improved dyspnea, ambulating independently DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS: Aspirin 81mg PO daily, clopidogrel 75mg PO daily for 6 months, amlodipine 5mg PO daily, atorvastatin 20mg PO daily, alendronate 70mg PO weekly DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: Continue dual antiplatelet therapy for 6 months. Follow up with cardiology in 1 week. Repeat echocardiogram in 1 month. Avoid strenuous activity for 2 weeks. Monitor for signs of stroke or valve dysfunction. Return for fever, chest pain, or shortness of breath.

text:
Diagnosis: Acute viral bronchiolitis

Key Signs:  Mild dehydrations, mild-to-moderate respiratory distress, fussy, nasal flaring, subcostal and intercostal retractions present. Diffuse wheezing, coarse crackles, prolonged expiratory phase noted. Capillary refill 3 seconds.

Treatment  Given: nasal suctioning and humidified oxygen,PO hydration trial inadequate,started on IV fluids D5 ½NS.

Discharge Condition: Improved, feeding well, no oxygen requirement.

data.text: ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acute viral bronchiolitis with mild dehydration PATIENT: 4-month-old male, previously healthy, with 3-day history of rhinorrhea and cough, now with progressive increased work of breathing over past 12 hours. Mother reports reduced feeding (2 oz per feed versus usual 5 oz), decreased wet diapers (last wet diaper 8 hours ago), and irritability. Sibling recently had upper respiratory infection. Infant attends daycare. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Vitals: HR 168, RR 56, Temp 99.4°F, O2 sat 91% on room air. Infant in mild-to-moderate respiratory distress, fussy. Nasal flaring, subcostal and intercostal retractions present. Diffuse wheezing, coarse crackles, prolonged expiratory phase noted. Capillary refill 3 seconds. IMAGING: Chest X-ray shows peribronchial thickening, hyperinflation, no focal consolidation PROCEDURE PERFORMED: None HOSPITAL COURSE: Diagnosis of acute viral bronchiolitis, likely RSV given sick contacts and seasonal pattern. Mild dehydration noted. Started on nasal suctioning and humidified oxygen 2L nasal cannula, O2 saturation improved to 95%. PO hydration trial inadequate, started on IV fluids D5 ½NS at maintenance rate. Monitored closely for apnea given age <6 months. Improved over 48 hours with better feeding. Oxygen discontinued at 36 hours. No apneic episodes observed. DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: Acute viral bronchiolitis, likely RSV. Resolved mild dehydration. CONSULTATIONS: Pediatrics CONDITION ON DISCHARGE: Improved, feeding well, no oxygen requirement DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS: None DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: Continue small frequent feeds. Use saline nasal drops and bulb suction as needed. Humidified air may help. Follow up with pediatrician in 2-3 days or sooner if worsening. Return immediately for difficulty breathing, blue lips, lethargy, or refusal to feed. Siblings should practice good hand hygiene.

value.text: right anterior cervical lymph node (2 cm)

text:
Diagnosis:  Kawasaki disease with coronary artery involvement

Key Signs: fever ≥5 days, bilateral conjunctival injection without discharge, mucosal changes, rash, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

Treatment  Given: IVIG 2g/kg IV and high-dose aspirin 80mg/kg/day

Discharge  Condition:Stable, afebrile, improved irritability, feeding well

data.text: ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Kawasaki disease with coronary artery involvement PATIENT: 3-year-old male with 6 days of persistent high fever (up to 103°F), now with bilateral conjunctival injection without discharge, cracked lips, strawberry tongue, polymorphous rash over trunk and extremities, edema of hands and feet, and enlarged right anterior cervical lymph node (2 cm). Worsening irritability and decreased appetite. No cough or rhinorrhea. LABORATORY RESULTS: CRP 72 mg/L (elevated), ESR 72 mm/hr (elevated), platelets 420 × 10³/μL (elevated), WBC 15.2 × 10³/μL, albumin 2.9 g/dL (low), ALT 78 U/L (elevated) ECHOCARDIOGRAM: Mild coronary artery dilation noted. Proximal RCA 2.8mm (z-score +2.2), LAD 2.6mm (z-score +2.0). No aneurysms. Normal ventricular function. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) infusion HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient meets all 5 classic criteria for Kawasaki disease: fever ≥5 days, conjunctivitis, mucosal changes, rash, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiac involvement present with mild coronary artery dilation. Treated with IVIG 2g/kg IV over 12 hours and high-dose aspirin 80mg/kg/day divided every 6 hours. Fever resolved 24 hours after IVIG administration. Irritability and feeding improved. Platelets peaked at 650 × 10³/μL on day 10. Desquamation of fingertips began on day 14 as expected. DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: Kawasaki disease with mild coronary artery dilation, status post IVIG treatment CONSULTATIONS: Pediatric cardiology CONDITION ON DISCHARGE: Stable, afebrile, improved irritability, feeding well DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS: Aspirin 81mg (3-5 mg/kg/day) PO daily for 6-8 weeks DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: Continue low-dose aspirin for 6-8 weeks as directed. Avoid live vaccines for 11 months post-IVIG due to antibody interference. Follow up with cardiology at 2 weeks, 6-8 weeks, and 1 year with repeat echocardiograms to monitor coronary arteries. Return immediately for recurrent fever, irritability, chest pain, or difficulty breathing. Watch for continued desquamation of fingers and toes over next few weeks (normal).

text:
Primary Diagnosis:  Anaphylaxis secondary to peanut exposure

Key Symptoms/Signs:  acute onset, skin/mucosal involvement, respiratory compromise, cardiovascular compromise

Diagnostic Evidence:  Vitals: BP 85/50 (hypotensive), HR 125, RR 32, O2 sat 88% 

Procedure Performed: None

Complications: None

Discharge Status: Stable, symptoms resolved, breathing comfortably

data.text: ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Anaphylaxis secondary to peanut exposure PATIENT: 28-year-old female with known peanut allergy presents with acute onset shortness of breath, facial swelling, and full-body hives starting 10 minutes after eating at restaurant. Patient suspects cross-contamination with peanuts. Symptoms started with oral pruritus, rapidly progressed to throat tightness, difficulty swallowing, and sensation of "throat closing." Also reports lightheadedness. Patient forgot EpiPen at home. Friend drove her immediately to emergency department. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON ARRIVAL: Vitals: BP 85/50 (hypotensive), HR 125, RR 32, O2 sat 88% on room air. Patient anxious, in severe distress, speaking in short phrases. Angioedema of lips, tongue, and face present. Oropharynx erythematous with uvular edema. Tachycardia with weak pulses. Tachypnea with diffuse expiratory wheezes bilaterally. Diffuse urticaria over chest, abdomen, back, and extremities. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: None HOSPITAL COURSE: Diagnosis of anaphylaxis (severe, life-threatening allergic reaction) meeting criteria with acute onset, skin/mucosal involvement PLUS respiratory compromise PLUS cardiovascular compromise (hypotension). Immediate treatment administered: epinephrine 0.3mg (1:1000) IM into lateral thigh, high-flow oxygen via non-rebreather mask 15L/min, two large-bore IVs established with normal saline bolus 1 liter rapid infusion, diphenhydramine 50mg IV push, methylprednisolone 125mg IV push, famotidine 20mg IV push, and albuterol 2.5mg nebulized continuous. Within 8 minutes of epinephrine: BP improved to 95/60, throat tightness improving, wheezing decreased. At 23 minutes: BP 105/65, throat tightness resolved, wheezing minimal, angioedema improving. No second epinephrine dose needed. Patient admitted to ED observation unit for minimum 4-6 hour monitoring due to risk of biphasic reaction (recurrence in 4-8 hours). At 5 hours post-epinephrine: vitals stable (BP 118/72, HR 78, O2 sat 99% on room air), angioedema resolved, urticaria 90% resolved, breathing comfortable, no recurrence observed. DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: Anaphylaxis secondary to peanut exposure, resolved CONSULTATIONS: Allergy/immunology CONDITION ON DISCHARGE: Stable, symptoms resolved, breathing comfortably DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS: Prednisone 60mg PO daily for 3 days, diphenhydramine 25mg PO every 6 hours PRN for 3 days, famotidine 20mg PO twice daily for 3 days, albuterol inhaler 2 puffs every 4 hours PRN, EpiPen 0.3mg auto-injector × 2 (prescribed, must carry at all times) DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: Strict peanut avoidance at all times. ALWAYS carry two EpiPens. Learn proper EpiPen technique: inject into outer thigh, hold 3 seconds, call 911 immediately after use even if symptoms improve. Wear medical alert bracelet. Read all food labels carefully. Inform restaurants of severe allergy. Follow up with allergist within 1 week (referral provided). Return immediately for any recurrence of throat tightness, difficulty breathing, hives, or lightheadedness.

value.text: 30 mL/kg normal saline bolus (2 liters rapidly infused)
Acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease
Acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease

text:
Primary Diagnosis:  Septic shock secondary to urosepsis, with acute encephalopathy and acute kidney injury.

Key Symptoms/Signs: Tachycardic, tachypnea with coarse breath sounds bilaterally. Suprapubic tenderness noted. Skin warm and flushed. Neurologically oriented only to name. Persistent hypotension requiring vasopressors and lactate >2 mmol/L

Diagnostic Evidence:  Urinalysis positive for nitrites, positive leukocyte esterase, many bacteria. Patient meets sepsis-3 criteria with suspected infection and SOFA score ≥2

Procedure Performed: None

Complications: None

Discharge Status: Improved, alert and oriented × 3, hemodynamically stable off vasopressors, creatinine improving

data.text: ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Septic shock secondary to urosepsis with acute encephalopathy and acute kidney injury PATIENT: 78-year-old female with history of type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease stage 3, hypertension, and recurrent urinary tract infections found confused and febrile at home by family. Patient had 3-day history of dysuria and urinary frequency. Today became lethargic, confused, and tachypneic. EMS called. EMS vitals: BP 78/45, HR 135, Temp 103.8°F, RR 32, O2 sat 87% on room air. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON ARRIVAL: Vitals: BP 82/48, HR 138, RR 34, Temp 104.1°F, O2 sat 86% on room air. Ill-appearing, obtunded. Tachycardic, no murmurs. Tachypnea with coarse breath sounds bilaterally. Suprapubic tenderness noted. Skin warm and flushed. Neurologically oriented only to name. LABORATORY RESULTS: CBC shows WBC 19.5 × 10³/μL, platelets 130 × 10³/μL. Lactate 5.1 mmol/L (elevated). Creatinine 2.4 mg/dL (baseline 1.4 mg/dL). Urinalysis positive for nitrites, positive leukocyte esterase, many bacteria. Blood cultures × 2 and urine culture collected. Sodium 130 mEq/L. IMAGING: Chest X-ray clear, no pneumonia PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Central line placement, Foley catheter insertion HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient meets sepsis-3 criteria with suspected infection and SOFA score ≥2. Meets septic shock criteria with persistent hypotension requiring vasopressors and lactate >2 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation. Immediate sepsis bundle initiated: 30 mL/kg normal saline bolus (2 liters rapidly infused), broad-spectrum antibiotic ceftriaxone 2g IV started within 1 hour, blood cultures obtained before antibiotics. Norepinephrine started at 6 mcg/min for persistent hypotension. High-flow nasal cannula 40 L/min, FiO2 50%, SpO2 improved to 94%. Foley catheter inserted (30mL urine on insertion, oliguria noted), strict intake/output monitoring. At 2 hours post-treatment: BP improved to 102/60 on norepinephrine, HR 118, lactate trending down from 5.1 to 3.8 mmol/L, mentation slightly improved (oriented × 2). Blood cultures later grew E. coli sensitive to ceftriaxone. Continued ICU care with gradual improvement. DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: Septic shock secondary to E. coli urosepsis, resolved. Acute encephalopathy, resolved. Acute kidney injury on chronic kidney disease, improving. CONSULTATIONS: Intensive care medicine, infectious disease, nephrology CONDITION ON DISCHARGE: Improved, alert and oriented × 3, hemodynamically stable off vasopressors, creatinine improving DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS: Ceftriaxone 1g IV daily for total 7-day course (to complete at home with home health), metformin held temporarily, lisinopril 5mg daily (reduced dose), amlodipine 5mg daily DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: Complete full 7-day course of IV antibiotics via home health. Drink plenty of fluids. Follow up with primary care in 1 week and nephrology in 2 weeks. Monitor for fever, confusion, decreased urination, or worsening weakness. Practice good perineal hygiene. Consider prophylactic antibiotics given recurrent UTIs—discuss with primary care doctor. Return immediately for fever >100.4°F, confusion, difficulty breathing, or decreased urine output.
